description: Aaron Sher  added  3 new photos . August 12, 1984 - Closing ceremonies of LA Olympics that may have changed the Olympics for the better.  Back then IOC had less than $40 Million in the bank - today well over a $1 Billion.  The model used by the LAOOC has now been the basis of the IOC - sponsors, TV contracts, legacy, etc.   LA84 Foundation is still going strong and using money from LA to promote youth sports in the LA area since the games.     Its been 30 years but the memories and pride of those accomplishment in 1984 are still with all those that had a role in the Games.

description: Peter Lewin A legendary bowler and later broadcaster, but I remember seeing him hit a century when Australia toured South Africa 1957-58. I got his autograph. The Ausies murdered the Springboks. A few years later, when Benaud was gone from the team and Bobby Simpson was leading Australia, South Africa beat them 5-0 in the test series. That was the beginning of the SA dream team, led by Peter Van der Merwe and later Allie Bacher, featuring Barry Richards, Eddie Barlow, Graeme Pollock, Peter Pollock, Collin Bland, Mike Proctor, and others whose names I cannot remember right now. Benaud introduced the kind of aggressive cricket that characterized that team. It may have been the best national team of all time. It never reached its full potential because of the sports boycott that was imposed on South Africa for many years.   Often controversial, cricket owes him a lot.    Larry White   Bob Lawson   Bernard Baruch Taylor   Aaron Sher

description: Yan Huckendubler  added  22 new photos  — with  Aaron Sher  and  9 others . Olympic memories (5) – Beijing 2008  Complete change of role for me in Beijing for the 2008 Olympic Games: instead of been a Media Attaché for the Canadian Team, I was appointed as a Media Officer for the International Hockey Federation (FIH). So, instead of working as an intermediary between the athletes of various sports and the media, I was completely on the media side, and only at the (field) hockey venue.  Our team was top notch, with very experienced FIH Media Officers  Elisabeth Fuerst  and  Richard Stainthorpe , plus  Chantal Janssen , a statistician from the Netherlands (working for Infostrada) who was delivering fascinating facts during matches such as “if Germany scores another goal in this half, it will be their 300th goal at the Olympics and the first time since 1992 that half time is reached with a 5-goal difference” (or something along these lines).  The four of us got along very well, and we took advantage of arriving a few days early to visit all the mandatory tourist spots in Beijing, including a memorable hike on the Great Wall in boiling muggy heat.   We were also invited to attend the Opening Ceremony (fantastically choreographed with thousands of musicians, dancers and performers, but lacking a little on the emotional side for our western taste), then it was a non-stop grind 14 days in a row with 6 matches a day…  Our daily routine did not vary: leaving the hotel around 6:30am (may be 7:00am some days…) to be ready for the first match of the day at 8:30am, two matches (on one pitch) in the morning session (we were doing “live commentary” of all the matches in this pre-Twitter era) , lunch break usually in the cafeteria of the Main Press Centre (a short shuttle ride away), then four matches in the afternoon/evening session (on two pitches), then finalizing all the reports, updating the FIH web site (with an antiquated tool…) including uploading the pictures taken by FIH photographer Gordon Morrison. As if this was not enough, we were asked at the last minute to also publish a daily 4-page newsletter, with articles, stats and pictures that was printed during the night and distributed in the morning in various VIP lounges.  So by the time we wrapped up, there was really only time to figure out how to go back to the hotel, then crash for a few hours and repeat… It was a tad unfortunate for my colleagues, all in their first Olympics, who never had the chance to experience anything outside of the hockey venue during their stay…  To break this routine, one morning I realized when arriving at the venue that I had forgotten my accreditation at the hotel (rookie mistake…). I explained to the taxi driver the situation and he immediately switched to emergency mode, driving me back to the hotel way over the speed limit, honking all the time, going through a couple of red lights and even driving some sections on the left side of the road! He screeched to a halt in front of the hotel and I felt obliged to play along and dash in and out of the hotel. When we arrived back at the venue in record time, the taxi driver seemed extremely pleased of his feat, but only charged me the regular price and adamantly refused the tip I was offering him.  Exchanges with the local volunteers (and drivers) were sometimes made difficult by the language barrier, but I found everybody trying very hard to make things work for us, all the time with large friendly smiles.  The Canadian (field) hockey team started slowly with a loss vs. Australia (1-6), then had close matches vs. Pakistan (1-3), the Netherlands (2-4), Great Britain (tie 1-1) and South Africa (win 5-3). They then lost in classification to Belgium to finish 10th, on par with their predecessors in Sydney (2000), Los Angeles (1984) and Montreal (1976). Yan Huckendubler

description: Jonathan Cook  added  7 new photos  — with  Peter Caulder  and  Jacques Odendaal . Aaaaa-aaaaand we're ON!   👍 💯 🏆 😎 👊 💪 📝 😯 😀 !!!  It's Day 1 of the much-anticipated Dual International Series and the Tri Nations tournament is underway with Namibia U18A pocketing a third minute Go-aaa-aaaal!   Tentative SA U16B outletting from deep defence on the immaculate Pretoria Boys High School turf enabled a lightning  ⚡  quick turnover when the alert Nam forward and captain Charl Brits picked the perfect passing option left to his vice-captain Dylan Finch, the striker showing he's got quick hands  👐  given the speed of the mid-height flick.   After concerted pressing SA U16B equalised in the 21st minute when Matt Dewar, son of the outstanding former striker Andy Dewar finished in stuuu-uuuning fashion with a powerful turf-burner from top-right of the strike zone!  At 1-1 the game hyped to another level and SA penalty corner drag-flick king Cody Posthumus of Grey High School fired a mid-post ripper that kissed the wrong side of the upright.   SA U16B defender and captain Ivann van der Merwe of Paul Roos Gymnasium made a crucial intercept in the 24th minute within ominously close range of the goalline that extinguished a highly possible Petros Theron goal-shot opportunity.   Nam  🔟  Ivan Semedo got off a reverse-stick snap-shot in the 32nd minute that whizzed comfortably high and wide of the left post.   The 35 minutes of the first half had come and gone with astonishing speed such was the intensity and high tempo of this opening first match in the Tri Nations.  It's 35 minutes in each of the two halves with a seven-minute halftime.  The second half got off to a definitive start when first Dylan Greeff of Pretoria Boys High School and then Posthumus - after the onsong Dewar had earned a PC - brought out two stu-uuuuning stick saves from Nam keeper Franco Lotter of Windhoek Gymnasium.   The game exploded in the 46th and 47th minutes when Nam frontrunners Percy Barthram and deputy skipper Finch finished in stuuu-uuuning fashion to leapfrog South Africa's north western neighbours into a 4-1 lead with 23 minutes left in this pulsating match.   SA had enough time to play catch-up but the Nam defensive line - inspired by the sharpest of finishing from their strikeforce held firm.   However the fierce pressure imposed on Nam by the determined SA posse of f Peter Caulder d umpire Peter Caulder to dish out two-minute sin-bins to Semedo and Jurgen von der Fecht before Semedo collected a yellow card custard  🍮  slice  🍕  for another five minutes in the naughty chair.   The offences hurt the Nam lads when penalty corner injector Lombard slapped home the return pass from top of the D in the 59th minute and Greeff nailed down the third SA goal five minutes from the full-time hooter.   Now within a single precious goal of parity the South African lads poured forward with renewed vigour!  And with a nerve-wracking 81 seconds left on the clock  🕒  penalty corner injector Lombard re-enacted a carbon copy of his superb set-piece strike  🔟  minutes earlier to earn the young Saffas a thrilling 4-4 draw!  What a fantabulous first chapter of the series and it's going to take some classic contests to better this one! Michelle Finch Tsitsi Carol Musarurwa Semedo Cailean Schickerling Angela Dewar Neil Jonathan Cook Suzette Lotter Desiree Klemp

description: Sally Scarborough  was with  Aaron Sher  and  27 others . RIPPLE EFFECT  As all of you tagged know, all of our lives have been changed,   without any choice, by individuals claiming to be” moving a different  direction”. For this I am shocked, and a little ashamed, not of my  actions or any of yours, but of some people in the organization that  I have loved and invested a ton of time, sweat and tears in over the about last 20  or so years. There have been lots of interesting times, good and bad – fish  on the fields, frost, alligators, bathrooms that opened into bus routes,   found teeth, lost cards, found cards, red cards, gold panning, karaoke,   bus rides, bathroom incidents, broken keys, ruined shoes, eye patches,  dust devils, yellow cards, lost tents, wet cards, funny hats, golf cart races,  interesting menus, water bottle scooping, rain delays, slides, garbage hunts,  yard sales, parties, green cards, late hours, hot turf, dead bugs, the cult…the list  could go on and on…but mostly there has been friends, togetherness, love,  hard work and respect for each other. I am sad beyond words that I will  never get to tell you a REAL good bye or thank you, that some of you I will   never see again. I am sure that if we knew “the last time” was the   last time -we all would have done things differently.  So, to the cult leader, I say  - Thank you, for believing in me, for everything  You taught me, for giving me the chance to give back to the sport I love and   for your unconditional dedication to the sport you  love . You deserve so much better and I love you. To each of you, I say   thank you for your time, dedication and putting up with me – I will miss  each of you and the many times we worked together.   Try to keep in touch - even if only on facebook.  Do good, be kind, love well.  -sally  Please share with anyone that I may have forgotten!
